abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Communication Sector
            Reform Project for Mozambique were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            low or negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: when the implementation
            capacity of the borrower is limited, more effort/resources
            are needed to keep the project implementation unit and the
            implementing agencies actively involved and proactive: i.e.
            effort to encourage each implementing agency to have an
            empowered focal point in charge of project components,
            effort from the World Bank (WB) to keep those staff updated
            especially in case of high turnover. In a country that shows
            overall limited project implementation effectiveness, it is
            also important to define a realistic time line for project
            implementation and/or scope of activities. Full development
            impact from liberalization of the sector, including
            privatization of the incumbent, can only be experienced when
            liberalization actions are comprehensive and timely. Three
            key factors are needed for a rural access component to be
            successful: a good strategy based on an accurate evaluation
            of the market components (supply and demand), the existence
            of the right balance of competition in the market and
            incentives mechanisms embedded in the tender process, and a
            swift implementation of the tender process so as to keep the
            investors committed.

5085317.trustfund:
TF027832-POSTAL SERVICE SECTOR TRUST
            FUND - DEUTSCHE POST/WORLD BANK PARTNERSHIP

abstracts.cdata!:
The Communication Sector Reform Project
            will improve the access, and quality of communications
            services in Mozambique, by creating a competitive
            environment, with private participation in the
            telecommunications, postal, and air transport
            infrastructure, and services. Project components will: 1)
            develop a telecommunication policy, through consulting
            services to reflect the principles of liberalization,
            independent regulation, and privatization of the Public
            Telecommunication Company (TDM). Assistance will also be
            provided to the Ministry of Transport and Communications in
            building capacity in sector analysis, policy formulation,
            and monitoring criteria to liaise throughout the reform
            process. Additionally, a comprehensive telecommunications,
            and postal legal, and regulatory framework will be prepared,
            by strengthening the Telecommunications and Postal
            Regulatory Authority's capacity, and, technical
            assistance (TA) will support TDM's privatization. A
            strategy for market-based rural access should establish
            provision of seed money, and universal fund access, while a
            modernization strategy will elaborate a postal policy
            focused on competitiveness to improve services, in addition
            to enabling legislation for an information, and
            communications (IC) technology strategy; 2) develop an air
            transport policy, and regulatory framework, by strengthening
            the capacity of the Civil Aviation Policy Unit, through the
            provision of TA, training, and consulting services, to
            restructure, and foster private participation of the
            national airline, and to implement the concession of the
            Maputo International Airport; and, 3) support project
            management, procurement, and financial management, and,
            finance IC campaign and dissemination.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Communication Sector Reform :
            environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental pre-audit of public
            enterprises for the Communication Sector Reform Project aims
            to assist the government to a) identify the extent of the
            existing environmental liabilities of public enterprises and
            rank them accordingly as to which needs full audit or no
            audit; b) broadly assess the environmental conditions at the
            enterprises to be privatized against the risk of being held
            responsible for damages after privatization; c) use the
            environmental pre-audit as a starting point for assessing
            the enterprise's environmental and health status prior
            to privatization; and d) assess the responsibility of
            monitoring and compliance of each party to meet the
            internationally accepted environmental standards. The
            pre-audit will be conducted in two phases: focusing to
            privatize the telecommunication company -- Telecommunicacoes
            de Mozambique (TDM), the national airline -- Linheas Aeras
            de Mozambique (LAM) , and to concession the Maputo
            International Airport (MIA). For MIA, a partial pre-audit
            will be required to deal with solid waste disposal,
            treatment of water, and VOA equipment. For LAM, no audit is
            required since the current fleet being operated does not
            pose any environmental concerns, For TDM, no audit is
            required since TDM has been able to resolve the main
            concerns relating to the decommissioning of cross-bar
            exchanges and other analog equipment with a Zimbabwean enterprise.
